awd_titl_txt: EAGER: The impact of mentorship networks on academic research
awd_abstract_narration:
Mentorship provides an important influence on how scientific researchers develop professionally. Most researchers spend several years training under just one or two graduate and/or postdoctoral mentors, suggesting that this small number of relationships can have large impact on subsequent careers. Mentorship can have both direct intellectual benefits to the trainee through the learning of new skills and concepts and indirect social benefits through engagement with the social network of the mentor. Networks of mentors and trainees can be represented by a directional graph resembling a traditional family tree. This project develops a large database of academic mentorship relationships and tools for analyzing the impact of mentorship on scientific careers. Development of this database addresses the mission of the Science of Science & Innovation Policy program. The data will be made open-access for general use by the public, providing a new resource for studying the dynamics of academic research fields. More generally, the Academic Family Tree represents a successful crowdsourcing project and provides an example for other efforts to engage the public in scientific research projects.

This project uses semantic and graph theoretic analyses to characterize the impact of mentorship networks on professional success and on the evolution of research fields. This project uses crowdsourcing to expand the Academic Family Tree, a public, web-based database of formal mentoring relationships (doctoral and postdoctoral) across all fields of academic research. Researchers in the mentorship database are linked to publication metadata in multiple publication databases and to funding data in the Federal RePORTER database. Semantic and graph theoretic analyses are used to determine what features of the mentorship network influence the subsequent careers of trainees. Focusing on trainees with at least two mentors, these analyses evaluate direct intellectual impact of mentor expertise, measured by latent semantic analysis of publications, and indirect social impact, measured by the similarity of the lineage of the two mentors in the larger academic genealogy. Two measures of trainees' professional success are considered: the number of trainees they themselves mentor and their ability to obtain research funding.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the impact of formal mentoring relationships on career outcomes in academic research. We developed the Academic Family Tree (https://academictree.org/), an online, crowdsourced database that documents graduate and postdoctoral training relationships across more than 50 research fields. We have also linked researchers to publication data and federal funding databases. These data can be browsed by any user in an intuitive web interface.

We characterized professional success based on each researcher?s ?proliferation rate?, that is, the number of trainees they have mentored  (Figure 1A). We also performed semantic analysis of publication text to measure a semantic similarity between researchers (Figure 1B). Each researcher is described by a vector in a high-dimensional space, based on the relative frequency with which they used different words in their publications. Similarity between researchers is quantified by the angle between their semantic vectors.

Using these measurements, we identified new factors that impact the sucess of new researchers. First, if a mentor has a high proliferation rate, their trainee is also likely to themselves have a high proliferation rate, indicating professional success. This effect is stronger for postdoctoral training. Second, we observed a positive effect of intellectual synthesis. A researcher is more likely to be successful if they train with two mentors whose work is semantically different, as long as the trainee establishes semantic similarity between their own work and that of both mentors. In other words, a researcher will be successful if they are able to draw on the disparate expertise of their two mentors and combine that expertise in a new research program. This study is published in a report in Nature Communications (Li?nard et. al 2018).

As part of this project, we also made several improvements to the front- and back and of the Academic Family Tree website to make it more stable and easier to use. The site now automatically updates researcher publication and funding date. In addition, users may now visualize and search among researchers based on their semantic similarity. Given the results of our study, we anticipate that the site will be useful for trainees seeking new areas to explore where they can perform their own synthesis. We have also formalized procedures for sharing data via an open source license and provided it to a number of groups to perform their own analysis.
